required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Comparison of Solid and Soluble Forms of Cold and Influenza Remedies
clinical_study.official_title: A Comparison of Solid and Soluble Forms of Cold and Influenza Remedies

brief_summary.textblock: The study is designed to investigate whether paracetamol from a hot remedy reaches the plasma faster than standard paracetamol tablets. The study will also assess the gastrointestinal transit of two oral cold and influenza ('flu') formulations using gamma scintigraphy. It is postulated that paracetamol in solution, such as from cold and 'flu' hot remedies, provides a greater early exposure compared to standard paracetamol tablets. In addition, the pharmacokinetic (PK) profile of paracetamol in the two formulations will be investigated.

primary_outcome.measure: Time to Reach Plasma Paracetamol Concentration of 0.25 μg/mL (Microgram Per Milliliter)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken within 15-30 minutes prior to dosing and at 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20, 30, 45, 90, 120 and 180 minutes post-dose
primary_outcome.description: Time to reach plasma paracetamol concentration of 0.25 μg/mL was determined using plasma concentration time profiles.

secondary_outcome.measure: Area Under the Concentration/Time Curve From 0 to 30 Minutes (Min) (AUC 0-30 Min)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken within 15-30 min prior to dosing and at 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20, 30, 45, 90, 120 and 180 minutes post-dose
secondary_outcome.description: AUC (0-30 min) was determined from paracetamol plasma concentration time profiles using trapezoidal rule.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken within 15-30 min prior to dosing and at 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20, 30, 45, 90, 120 and 180 minutes post-dose
secondary_outcome.description: AUC (0-60 min) was determined from paracetamol plasma concentration time profiles using trapezoidal method.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken within 15-30 min prior to dosing and at 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20, 30, 45, 90, 120 and 180 minutes post-dose
secondary_outcome.description: Cmax was determined using plasma paracetamol concentration time profile.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken within 15-30 min prior to dosing and at 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20, 30, 45, 90, 120 and 180 minutes post-dose
secondary_outcome.description: Time after administration when the maximum plasma concentration was reached.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Onset of Gastric Emptying
secondary_outcome.description: The individual anterior and posterior images were assessed using Gamma Scintigraphy images and WebLink Image Analysis program to determine the time to onset of gastric emptying of hot drink remedy and standard paracetamol tablets.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Completion of Gastric Emptying
secondary_outcome.description: Time to completion of gastric emptying of hot drink remedy and standard paracetamol tablets was assessed using Gamma Scintigraphy images and WebLink image analysis program. Completion of gastric emptying was confirmed by two consecutive images with negligible gastric activity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Onset and Completion of Disintegration of Reference Tablets
secondary_outcome.description: Qualitative onset and completion of tablet disintegration was determined using Gamma scintigraphy images and WebLink image analysis program.

arm_group.description: Paracetamol, phenylephrine and ascorbic acid to be administered in 150 milliliters (mL) of hot water.
Two paracetamol 500 mg tablets to be administered with 150 mL of hot water.

intervention.description: Present in both test and active comparator

criteria.textblock:
- Healthy male volunteers
- Body mass index between 18.0-29.9 kg/m^2

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited at one clinical study site in Glasgow.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Of 37 participants screened, 12 participants did not meet the study criteria. Remaining 25 participants were randomized into the study.

group.title: Hot Drink Remedy First, Then Standard Paracetamol Tablets
group.description: Participants received one sachet of hot drink remedy containing 1000 milligram (mg) paracetamol, 10 mg phenylephrine and 40 mg ascorbic acid in 150 milliliter (mL) of radio-labeled water (first intervention period). After a washout period of minimum two days, a single dose of two radio-labeled tablets of standard paracetamol (500 mg each) with 150 mL water were administered (second intervention period).

group.title: Standard Paracetamol Tablets First, Then Hot Drink Remedy
group.description: Participants received a single dose of two radio-labeled tablets of standard paracetamol (500 mg each) with 150 mL of water (first intervention period). After a washout period of minimum two days, one sachet of hot drink remedy with 150 mL of radio-labeled water was administered (second intervention period).

group.title: All Randomized Participants
group.description: All randomized participants who received a study treatment during the cross over study.

outcome.title: Time to Reach Plasma Paracetamol Concentration of 0.25 μg/mL (Microgram Per Milliliter)
outcome.description: Time to reach plasma paracetamol concentration of 0.25 μg/mL was determined using plasma concentration time profiles.
outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken within 15-30 minutes prior to dosing and at 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20, 30, 45, 90, 120 and 180 minutes post-dose
outcome.population: Modified Intent-To-Treat (MITT) population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in at least one of the two study periods.

group.title: Hot Drink Remedy
group.description: Participants received one sachet of hot drink remedy powder containing 1000 mg paracetamol, 10 mg phenylephrine and 40 mg ascorbic acid dissolved in 150 mL of radio-labeled water.

group.title: Standard Paracetamol Tablets
group.description: Participants received a single dose of two radio-labeled tablets of standard paracetamol (500 mg each) with 150 mL of water.

measure.title: Time to Reach Plasma Paracetamol Concentration of 0.25 μg/mL (Microgram Per Milliliter)
measure.description: Time to reach plasma paracetamol concentration of 0.25 μg/mL was determined using plasma concentration time profiles.
measure.population: Modified Intent-To-Treat (MITT) population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in at least one of the two study periods.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis was no difference between test hot drink and standard paracetamol tablets.
analysis.estimate_desc: Hodges-Lehmann estimate of median difference was determined.

outcome.title: Area Under the Concentration/Time Curve From 0 to 30 Minutes (Min) (AUC 0-30 Min)
outcome.description: AUC (0-30 min) was determined from paracetamol plasma concentration time profiles using trapezoidal rule.
outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken within 15-30 min prior to dosing and at 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20, 30, 45, 90, 120 and 180 minutes post-dose
outcome.population: MITT population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in at least one of the two study periods.

measure.title: Time to Maximum Plasma Concentration (Tmax)

outcome.title: Time to Onset of Gastric Emptying
outcome.description: The individual anterior and posterior images were assessed using Gamma Scintigraphy images and WebLink Image Analysis program to determine the time to onset of gastric emptying of hot drink remedy and standard paracetamol tablets.
outcome.population: Period Level MITT population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in one of the two study periods. Gastric emptying endpoints were only measured in the first period for each participant.

group.title: Hot Drink Remedy
group.description: Participants received one sachet of hot drink remedy powder containing 1000 mg paracetamol, 10 mg phenylephrine and 40 mg ascorbic acid dissolved in 150 mL of radio-labeled water.

group.title: Standard Paracetamol Tablets
group.description: Participants received a single dose of two radio-labeled tablets of standard paracetamol (500 mg each) with 150 mL of water.

measure.title: Time to Onset of Gastric Emptying
measure.description: The individual anterior and posterior images were assessed using Gamma Scintigraphy images and WebLink Image Analysis program to determine the time to onset of gastric emptying of hot drink remedy and standard paracetamol tablets.
measure.population: Period Level MITT population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in one of the two study periods. Gastric emptying endpoints were only measured in the first period for each participant.

outcome.title: Time to Completion of Gastric Emptying
outcome.description: Time to completion of gastric emptying of hot drink remedy and standard paracetamol tablets was assessed using Gamma Scintigraphy images and WebLink image analysis program. Completion of gastric emptying was confirmed by two consecutive images with negligible gastric activity.
outcome.population: Period Level MITT population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in one of the two study periods. Gastric emptying endpoints were only measured in the first period for each participant.

measure.population: Period Level MITT population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in one of the two study periods. Gastric emptying endpoints were only measured in the first period for each participant.

outcome.title: Time to Onset and Completion of Disintegration of Reference Tablets
outcome.description: Qualitative onset and completion of tablet disintegration was determined using Gamma scintigraphy images and WebLink image analysis program.
outcome.population: Period Level MITT population: all randomized participants with any post baseline pharmacokinetic measurement or scintigraphic measurement, and had evaluable data in one of the two study periods. Tablet Disintegration endpoints were only measured in the first period for each participant.

group.description: Participants received a single dose of two radio-labeled tablets of standard paracetamol (500 mg each) with 150 mL of water.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events were collected from the start of the treatment, and until 5 days following administration of the last dose of investigational product.

group.title: Hot Drink Remedy
group.description: Participants then received one sachet of hot drink remedy powder containing 1000 mg paracetamol, 10 mg phenylephrine and 40 mg ascorbic acid, which was dissolved in 150 mL of radio-labeled water.

group.title: Standard Paracetamol Tablets
group.description: Participants received a single dose of two radio-labeled tablets of standard paracetamol (500 mg each) with 150 mL of water.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: GSK agreements may vary with individual investigators, but will not prohibit any investigator from publishing. GSK supports the publication of results from all centers of a multi-center trial but requests that reports based on single-site data not precede the primary publication of the entire clinical trial.
